{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11897,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Chorizanthe staticoides, commonly known as Turkish rugging, is a drought-tolerant plant native to dry, rocky environments. It requires infrequent watering once established in your garden. During its growth period in spring, water it moderately, allowing the soil to dry between watering. During hotter months, reduce watering as the plant enters a dormant phase. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, as the plant does not tolerate waterlogged soil well. Overwatering is more of a threat than underwatering for this species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chorizanthe staticoides thrives in full sunlight, making it ideal for bright, open spaces in the garden. It requires a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight daily to maintain its compact growth and vibrant flowering. In areas with intense heat, afternoon shade can help protect it from potential scorching, though it is generally quite heat tolerant. If grown in partial shade, it may become leggy and produce fewer flowers, so choose a planting spot that maximizes sun exposure for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Chorizanthe staticoides is minimal, as it is a low-maintenance plant. Focus on removing dead or diseased stems to promote healthy growth. This can be done after the flowering season, typically towards late summer, to maintain its shape and encourage denser growth. Also, remove any debris that may collect among the plant's crown to prevent fungal issues. Since it is a small, ground-covering plant, regular pruning beyond cleaning up is not necessary, as it naturally forms a neat, compact mat."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Turkish rugging","description":"Chorizanthe staticoides is a species of flowering plant in the buckwheat family known by the common name Turkish rugging. It is endemic to California, where it is a common member of the flora in the chaparral and scrub habitats in a number of regions.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Turkish rugging"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Chorizanthe staticoides"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10994,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Raphanus sativus, commonly known as radish, requires consistent moisture to thrive. This plant prefers well-drained soil that is kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water them evenly, aiming for a soil moisture level that remains constant. Overwatering can lead to root rot, while prolonged dry periods can cause the roots to become woody and the plant may bolt. It is best to water the plants deeply at least once a week or more frequently during hotter periods, and mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce evaporation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Radishes are sun-loving plants that thrive best with full sunlight. They require at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day to grow properly. Adequate sunlight is crucial for proper root development and flavor. However, they can tolerate partial shade, particularly in regions with hot summer temperatures, where mid-day shade might prevent bolting. If radishes get too little sunlight, they may produce stunted root growth and an excess of leaves, so ensuring a sunny location is vital for a healthy crop."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Radishes do not require extensive pruning, but some attention to their growth can improve their yield and health. Remove yellowing or dead leaves to encourage airflow and reduce disease risk. It's also important to thin the seedlings when they are a few inches tall, to about 2 to 3 inches apart, ensuring adequate space for the roots to develop properly. If the radish tops become leggy or the plant is overcrowded, it can lead to poor root development, so regular monitoring and minor maintenance may be required to promote optimal growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"wild radish","description":"The radish (Raphanus raphanistrum subsp. sativus) is an edible root vegetable of the Brassicaceae family that was domesticated in Europe in pre-Roman times. Radishes are grown and consumed throughout the world, being mostly eaten raw as a crunchy salad vegetable. They have numerous varieties, varying in size, flavor, color, and length of time they take to mature. Radishes owe their sharp flavor to the various chemical compounds produced by the plants, including glucosinolate, myrosinase, and isothiocyanate....","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["wild radish"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Downy mildew","Cabbage root maggot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Raphanus sativus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10902,"attracts":["Birds","Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carya cordiformis, commonly known as bitternut hickory, prefers well-drained soil but can tolerate different moisture levels. It requires moderate watering, especially when young, to ensure proper root establishment. During prolonged dry spells, provide additional water to prevent stress, but be cautious to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Established trees typically handle natural rainfall well and need minimal supplemental watering. Use mulch to retain soil moisture and reduce evaporation. Always check the soil for moisture before watering, making sure the top few inches are dry before adding more water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carya cordiformis thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth, provide the tree with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial shade, but full sun will assure better growth rates, stronger branches, and more robust health. When planting, choose a location that allows the tree to capture as much sunlight as possible while considering future growth and potential shading from nearby structures or larger trees. Adequate sunlight is vital for photosynthesis and overall vigor, leading to an attractive tree with a strong, well-formed structure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carya cordiformis should generally be done during the dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the plant’s health and structure. For young trees, focus on developing a strong central leader and remove any competing branches. Avoid heavy pruning, as hickories naturally have a pleasing shape and structure. It's also important to remove any crossing or rubbing branches to prevent further damage. Prune sparingly to maintain natural form while ensuring good air circulation within the canopy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bitternut hickory","description":"Carya cordiformis, the bitternut hickory, also called bitternut or swamp hickory, is a large pecan hickory with commercial stands located mostly north of the other pecan hickories. Bitternut hickory is cut and sold in mixture with the true hickories. It is the shortest-lived of the hickories, living to about 200 years.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["bitternut hickory"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Hickory Shoot Canker","Hickory Bark Beetle"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Carya cordiformis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If you wish to control its height or spread, gentle trimming after its flowering stage will suffice. It is essential to water regularly, aiming to keep the soil evenly damp, particularly during its growing season in spring and early summer. Avoid overwatering which can lead to root rot, especially in poorly drained soils. During dormancy in fall and winter, reduce watering, allowing the topsoil to dry slightly between waterings. Ensure that the plant is in a location where it can retain some moisture, such as a partial shade garden spot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prosartes smithii thrives in partial to full shade, mimicking its natural forest floor habitat. It should be planted in a location where it receives indirect light, shielded from the harsh afternoon sun. Morning sunlight can be beneficial, but prolonged exposure to direct sunlight, especially during peak summer, can scorch the leaves. An ideal spot is under tall trees or on the north side of a building where it can get dappled sunlight, helping it maintain lush, deep green foliage and encourage blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Prosartes smithii mainly involves removing dead or damaged stems and leaves to maintain plant health and appearance. This should be done during the plant's dormant period, typically in late fall or early winter. Trim back the foliage carefully, just above the base if it starts looking ragged post-flowering. Avoid heavy pruning as the plant’s natural growth habit is best left somewhat undisturbed for optimal flowering next season. Regularly clearing spent flowers can encourage healthier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"largeflower fairybells","description":"Prosartes smithii is a North American species of flowering plants known by the common name largeflower fairybells. It is native to western North America from Vancouver Island in British Columbia south as far as Monterey County in California. If cultivating this fungus indoors, regular misting can help keep the humidity levels sufficient, but be careful to avoid waterlogged conditions as this can lead to rot. It's essential to find a balance, allowing for some drying out periods but maintaining overall high humidity for optimal growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Auricularia auricula-judae thrives in shaded environments, mimicking their natural habitat under forest canopies. They do not require direct sunlight and actually can become damaged if exposed to too much direct light. If growing them outdoors, position them in a spot with dappled sunlight at most. Indoors, indirect light or a dimly lit area is preferable. Maintaining a moderate to high humidity along with these light conditions will create a suitable environment for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning isn't applicable to Auricularia auricula-judae in the traditional sense, as it is a fungus. Instead, what you have to do is manage the substrate on which it grows. Harvesting the fungus promptly once it's mature will prevent any overgrowth which could lead to decay. Ensure the environment is clean and remove any dead or decayed wood nearby that might harbor pests or pathogens. This helps maintain a productive growth environment for the ears."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Jelly Ear","description":"Auricularia auricula-judae, known as the Jew's ear, wood ear, jelly ear or by a number of other common names, is a species of edible Auriculariales fungus found worldwide. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11103,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rosa canina, commonly known as the dog rose, requires moderate watering. It is best to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, water the plant thoroughly once a week, ensuring that the water reaches the deepest roots. However, in hot and dry weather, you may need to increase the frequency to twice a week. It's important to use well-drained soil and provide water early in the day to allow excess moisture to evaporate, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rosa canina thrives best in full sun conditions, which means it requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, optimal blooming and growth occur with ample sunlight. Plant it in a location where it won’t be overshadowed by larger plants or structures. Adequate sunlight helps to reduce disease occurrence by allowing the plant to dry off more quickly after rain or dew, thereby creating a less favorable environment for fungal diseases such as powdery mildew or black spot."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rosa canina is crucial for maintaining its health and shape. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring while the plant is still dormant. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to enhance air circulation and light penetration. Cut back about a third of the older stems to encourage new growth. Additionally, trim the plant to maintain its desired shape, but avoid drastic cuts. Regular deadheading during the blooming season can also promote continued flowering and neat appearance. Use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dog-rose","description":"Rosa canina, commonly known as the dog rose, is a variable climbing, wild rose species native to Europe, northwest Africa, and western Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North Africa","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Dog-rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rosa canina"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Target watering once every 10-14 days during dry periods, and reduce watering significantly in cooler months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pulsatilla vulgaris prefers full sunlight to partial shade conditions. Ensure it is placed in a location where it can bask in as much natural light as possible, especially during the spring and early summer months when it naturally flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pulsatilla vulgaris is relatively straightforward and should be done primarily to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Once the flowers have bloomed and started to die back, deadheading is advised to prevent self-seeding and promote a tidier appearance. Cut the spent blooms down to the base as they fade. If the foliage becomes unattractive during late summer, you can trim it back gently. Avoid cutting back drastically, as the plant needs its foliage to store energy for the next growing season. Clean up dead leaves and plant debris to avoid disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"European Pasqueflower","description":"Pulsatilla vulgaris (pasque flower, pasqueflower, common pasque flower, European pasqueflower, Dane's blood) is a species of flowering plant belonging to the buttercup family (Ranunculaceae), found locally on calcareous grassland in Europe. If cultivating mushrooms, maintaining a consistently damp substrate is crucial. Mist the substrate lightly to maintain humidity but avoid overwatering, which can lead to mold and other spoilage issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gomphidius glutinosus, or slimy spike-cap, thrives in the shaded, moist environments typical of forest floors, particularly under conifers. It does not require direct sunlight and usually grows well in dappled light or under full shade where the sunlight is filtered through the canopy. If cultivating, mimic these natural conditions by keeping them in a dimly lit area. Avoid exposing them to bright, direct sunlight as it could dry out the substrate and inhibit growth. Maintaining a stable and humid environment is more crucial than light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Since Gomphidius glutinosus is a mushroom, pruning does not apply in the conventional sense. However, if foraging or growing them, it is important to harvest them correctly to ensure future growth. Use a sharp knife to cut the stem at the base, leaving the mycelium intact in the ground or substrate. This practice helps to prevent damage to the mycelium network, promoting healthy regrowth of new fruiting bodies. Regular monitoring can also help remove any competing fungi or debris that could hinder growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Slimy Spike","description":"Gomphidius glutinosus, commonly known as the slimy spike-cap, is a gilled mushroom found in Europe & North America. Although it has gills, it is a member of the order Boletales, along with the boletes. The fruiting bodies sprout in pine, fir and spruce woodland in Europe in autumn. Initially, are completely covered with a slimy veil, breaking through to reveal a greyish or brownish-capped mushroom with decurrent greyish gills which sometimes resembles a child's top. It should be watered regularly during the growing season, especially during dry spells, to maintain consistent moisture. However, overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings. In periods of high temperatures or drought, increase the watering frequency, ensuring that the plant is not left to dry out excessively. Applying a layer of mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lonicera periclymenum thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. While it can tolerate some shade, full sun exposure results in more profuse flowering and vigorous growth. When planted in a location that receives morning sun and afternoon shade, the plant can grow successfully, but for optimal blooming, aim for at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Ensure proper airflow around the plant to avoid mildew problems often associated with shaded, humid conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lonicera periclymenum is essential to maintain its shape, beauty, and encourage vigorous growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches, and thin out congested areas to improve air circulation. To control its size and shape, cut back some of the older, longer stems to a healthy bud. After flowering, you can also lightly trim to shape and promote a compact form. Regular pruning will prevent the plant from becoming too leggy and will encourage a flush of flowers the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Honeysuckle","description":"Lonicera periclymenum, common names honeysuckle, common honeysuckle, European honeysuckle, or woodbine, is a species of flowering plant in the family Caprifoliaceae native to much of Europe, North Africa, Turkey and the Caucasus. In the UK it is one of two native honeysuckles, the...","family":null,"flower_color":"White, Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Northwest Africa"],"other_name":["Common Honeysuckle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Lonicera periclymenum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10798,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Calochortus venustus, or the butterfly mariposa lily, needs moderate watering throughout its growing season, which is typically in the spring and early summer. It prefers well-draining soil and doesn't tolerate waterlogged conditions, so it's important to ensure good drainage to avoid bulb rot. During the dormant period in the summer, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out almost completely between waterings, as the plant naturally experiences a dry period in its native habitats. Overall, aim to mimic natural rainfall patterns by reducing watering once flowering ends."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calochortus venustus thrives in full sun to partial shade. In its native habitat, it often grows in open meadows and sunny slopes where it receives abundant sunlight. For optimal growth, aim to give it at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. If growing in a particularly hot climate, providing some afternoon shade may protect it from intense heat. Ensuring adequate sunlight will encourage more robust flowering and healthier plants overall. Indoors, a south or west-facing window can work well for providing ample light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning isn't a major requirement for Calochortus venustus. However, it is beneficial to remove spent flowers to prevent seed formation and channel the plant’s energy back to the bulb. This can also help maintain a tidier appearance. Once the foliage begins to yellow and die back in late summer, it’s safe to trim it away. Avoid cutting green leaves, as they are still photosynthesizing and providing energy to the bulb. Pruning should be minimal and primarily focused on maintaining plant health and cleanliness."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Butterfly Mariposa Lily","description":"Calochortus venustus is a California species of flowering plants in the lily family known by the common name butterfly mariposa lily.","family":null,"flower_color":"White, Pink, Yellow, Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Western North America"],"other_name":["Butterfly Mariposa Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Calochortus venustus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10602,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vaccinium fuscatum, commonly known as black highbush blueberry, prefers consistently moist, well-drained soils. Water the plant regularly during the first growing season to establish a deep, extensive root system. Once established, it requires watering during dry, hot spells in the summer. Avoid waterlogging the roots, as this can lead to root rot. Applying a mulch layer helps retain soil moisture and reduce watering frequency. Always ensure the soil is moist but not soggy; overwatering can be as damaging as under-watering. In drier climates, drip irrigation or soaker hoses can be beneficial for maintaining moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vaccinium fuscatum thrives in full sun to partial shade. Full sunlight (at least 6 hours per day) is optimal for flower and fruit production, leading to more robust yields. However, the plant can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, where some afternoon shade can prevent scorching and stress. In shaded locations, expect fewer, smaller berries. Maintaining a balance between sunlight exposure and shelter from extreme afternoon heat will promote the healthiest growth and fruit production. Consider the sun pattern in your planting area and the plant's position relative to other structures or trees that may cast shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vaccinium fuscatum should be done during its dormant season, typically late winter. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged wood to promote healthy growth. Open up the center of the bush by cutting away crossing branches to improve air circulation. This also allows sunlight to penetrate the plant, encouraging fruit production. Younger shrubs require little pruning, mostly focusing on shaping and maintaining desired size. For mature plants, cut back one-third of the oldest branches annually to spur new growth. This method helps sustain vigor and ensures consistent fruiting from season to season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Black Highbush Blueberry","description":"Vaccinium fuscatum, commonly called black highbush blueberry, is a species of flowering plant in the heath family (Ericaceae). It is native eastern to North America, where it is found in Canada and the United States. Its typical natural habitat is wet areas such as bogs, pocosins, and swamps.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Black Highbush Blueberry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Vaccinium fuscatum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11600,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Chlorophyllum brunneum, commonly known as the Brown Parasol mushroom, does not require watering like typical houseplants as it thrives outdoors in natural environments. It typically grows in well-drained soils that are rich in organic matter, so maintaining these conditions naturally with rainfall is usually adequate. If cultivating outdoors, ensure that the soil stays slightly moist, especially during dry periods, but avoid waterlogging as this can encourage rot and fungal diseases. Adding organic mulch can help maintain soil moisture. If growing indoors or in a controlled setting, a light misting to maintain humidity can simulate outdoor conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chlorophyllum brunneum does not require direct sunlight as it is a type of mushroom. Instead, it thrives in shaded areas with indirect light. It typically grows in environments with dappled light, such as under trees or in the forest where it benefits from the filtered sunlight. In a cultivated setting, you should mimic these conditions by placing it in an area where it receives indirect sunlight or dappled shade. Managing light exposure is crucial as too much direct sunlight can dry out the environment, hindering its growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Chlorophyllum brunneum, as it is a mushroom and does not have parts that require cutting back like leaves or branches in plant care. However, it is beneficial to remove any old or decomposing mushrooms promptly to maintain a healthy environment and prevent the spread of mold and pests. Regularly inspect the growing area and carefully pick mature mushrooms to encourage more growth and prevent decay, ensuring you handle the fungi gently to avoid damaging the mycelium network essential for their reproduction."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Shaggy Parasol","description":"The Shaggy parasol is the common name for three closely related species of mushroom, Chlorophyllum rhacodes (or rachodes), C. olivieri and C. brunneum, found in North America, Europe and Southern Africa (the latter species is also found in Australia).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Shaggy Parasol"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Chlorophyllum brunneum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10703,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clinopodium douglasii prefers moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, especially during its growth period in spring and summer. The plant can tolerate some drought once it's established, but ideally, the top inch of soil should be kept moist. Reduce the frequency of watering during the fall and winter months as the plant enters a dormant phase. Ensure the pot or growing area has good drainage to prevent root rot, which can occur if the plant sits in water for too long."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clinopodium douglasii thrives in partial to full sun conditions. It grows best when it receives about 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching and help maintain the plant's health. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. In lower light conditions, the plant may become leggy or produce fewer flowers, so adjusting its positioning to ensure adequate sunlight can help it thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clinopodium douglasii is generally not necessary for its health, but occasional trimming can promote bushier growth and maintain its shape. If the plant becomes leggy or overgrown, you can trim back the stems by one-third in the early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or diseased foliage to encourage healthy development. Light pruning throughout its growing season can help direct energy towards more vigorous branches and a fuller appearance. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent any disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"yerba buena","description":"Clinopodium douglasii, or yerba buena, is a rambling aromatic herb of western and northwestern North America, ranging from maritime Alaska southwards to California. The plant takes the form of a sprawling, mat-forming perennial, and is especially abundant close to the coast. The name \"yerba buena\" derives from Spanish for \"good herb\" and is applied to various other plants. Molecular evidence places the species within the Clinopodium complex rather than Micromeria.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western North America"],"other_name":["yerba buena"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Clinopodium douglasii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensuring the pine remains healthy and is not under drought stress will indirectly maintain the mistletoe's water needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arceuthobium campylopodum does not have specific sunlight requirements, as it depends on its host tree for survival. The health of the host tree is crucial; ensuring it receives the appropriate amount of sunlight will indirectly support the mistletoe."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Arceuthobium campylopodum is usually aimed at managing the health of the host tree rather than maintaining the mistletoe itself. The primary method involves removing infected branches from the host tree to prevent the spread of the mistletoe. However, care should be taken not to prune excessively, which can stress the tree. Pruning should be conducted in the late winter or early spring when the tree is dormant, as this reduces stress and potential damage."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Western Dwarf-Mistletoe","description":"Arceuthobium campylopodum is a species of dwarf mistletoe known as western dwarf mistletoe. It is native to the low to moderate elevation coniferous forests of western North America. Reduce watering during the winter months when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spiraea douglasii thrives in full sun to part shade. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may result in fewer blooms and a leggier growth habit. In very hot or dry climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and reduce water stress. Adequate sunlight ensures lush foliage and vibrant flowering, making it important to select a planting spot that balances light and heat exposure according to your region's conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Spiraea douglasii is crucial to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches, cutting them back to healthy tissue. To manage size and encourage bushiness, prune the previous year's growth back by about one-third. You can also cut the oldest stems down to the base to stimulate new shoots, improving the plant's appearance. After flowering, light pruning can help maintain a tidy shape. Regular pruning will result in a more vigorous and floriferous plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rose Spirea","description":"Spiraea douglasii is a species of flowering plant in the rose family native to western North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10904,"attracts":["Squirrels","Birds","Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carya ovata, commonly known as the shagbark hickory, is a tree that prefers consistent moisture but can tolerate brief dry periods. It's important to water newly planted shagbark hickories regularly to establish a strong root system. Once established, they require watering mainly during prolonged dry spells, as they are relatively drought-tolerant for short periods. Water deeply so that the soil is moist but not waterlogged, taking care to ensure good drainage to prevent root rot. Ideally, the soil should be kept evenly moist but allowed to dry slightly between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Shagbark hickory trees thrive in full sun environments, meaning they prefer a minimum of six hours of direct, unfiltered sunlight per day. However, they can tolerate some light shade, particularly in the hotter climates where direct afternoon sun may be too intense. When planting, it's best to choose a location where the tree will not be shaded by taller structures or other large trees. Adequate sunlight exposure is crucial for the healthy development of their characteristic bark and prolific nut production, which also enhances their wildlife attractant properties."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Carya ovata should be carried out primarily in late winter or early spring before the tree breaks dormancy. Prune to maintain a healthy structure by removing any dead, diseased, or damaged wood. It's also important to trim any branches that cross or rub against each other to prevent wounds and disease entry. While shagbark hickories don't require much pruning, shaping for aesthetic purposes can also be done at this time. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the tree. Simply focus on maintaining its natural form and structural integrity."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"shagbark hickory","description":"Carya ovata, the shagbark hickory, is a common hickory in the Eastern United States and southeast Canada. However, to promote healthy growth, regular watering is recommended, especially during prolonged dry spells. Ensure that the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. This plant's watering needs can also be influenced by its growing environment, so adjust accordingly based on rainfall and humidity."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trifolium campestre thrives in full sun to partial shade. Water the plant whenever the top inch of the soil feels dry, allowing excess water to drain thoroughly. If indoors, ensure it is in a pot with drainage holes to prevent waterlogging. Avoid placing it in direct sun, as this can scorch the leaves, making them lose their natural vibrant patterns."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Goodyera pubescens is minimal and generally involves removing dead or decaying leaves to promote healthy growth and appearance. As this is a relatively low-growing and compact plant, significant pruning for shape is usually unnecessary. Ensure that pruning tools are sterilized to avoid introducing pathogens."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"downy rattlesnake plantain","description":"Goodyera pubescens, the downy rattlesnake plantain, is one of the most common orchids native to eastern North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10500,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Water Laburnum anagyroides (Common Laburnum) moderately; it prefers moist but well-drained soil. Ensure the soil is kept damp during the growing season, especially in dry spells. However, it's important not to let the plant's roots sit in waterlogged soil, as this can lead to root rot. Once established, Laburnum trees are fairly drought-tolerant, so allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings. In winter, reduce watering significantly to mimic the natural seasonal change and avoid waterlogged conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laburnum anagyroides thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal flowering, provide as much direct sunlight as possible, ideally aiming for six hours or more per day. If grown in partial shade, it may produce fewer blooms. The plant does best in sheltered locations protected from harsh winds, which can damage its delicate racemes. While it can tolerate some shade, insufficient light might lead to leggy growth and reduced overall vigor. Ensure that surrounding plants or structures do not overly shade the Laburnum."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Laburnum anagyroides should be done in late winter or early spring to maintain its shape and health. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote better air circulation and prevent fungal diseases. Also, prune to control size and shape by cutting back branches that are crossing or growing inward. Be cautious of poisonous branches and wear gloves while handling. Regular pruning helps prevent overgrowth and encourages more blooms the following season, but avoid heavy pruning as Laburnum doesn’t respond well to drastic cuts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Laburnum","description":"Laburnum anagyroides, the common laburnum, golden chain or golden rain, is a species in the subfamily Faboideae, and genus Laburnum. Once established, it can survive with very little water, usually only requiring supplemental watering during prolonged dry periods. It is best to let the soil dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In very hot or dry climates, occasional deep watering will help keep the plant looking its best without overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Muhlenbergia rigens prefers full sun to achieve optimal growth and health, which typically involves at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. Overall, providing Deer Grass with plenty of sunlight will ensure a healthy, attractive plant with vigorous foliage and ample flower spikes."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Muhlenbergia rigens is typically done in early spring to remove any dead or damaged foliage and to improve its appearance. Cut back the old, dry stems about a third to half of their height, or more if the plant has developed a lot of dead material. This stimulates new growth, maintaining its shape and vigor. Ensure you use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid damaging the plant. Pruning is not necessary if the plant looks healthy, as it naturally maintains a neat appearance."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"deergrass","description":"Muhlenbergia rigens, commonly known as deergrass, is a warm season perennial bunchgrass found in sandy or well drained soils below 7,000 feet (2,100 m) in elevation in the Southwestern United States and parts of Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["deergrass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Muhlenbergia rigens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Be cautious of root rot, particularly if grown in poorly draining soil or containers without adequate drainage holes. In natural settings, ragwort often copes with limited water supply, so err on the side of drier conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Jacobaea vulgaris thrives in full sunlight to partial shade. It can tolerate a wide range of light conditions but generally prefers a sunny environment for optimal growth and flowering. In regions with very hot summers, providing some afternoon shade might prevent stress and wilting. This plant is adaptable and can also grow fairly well in partial shade, although it might not flower as vigorously as it would under full sun. Ensure it gets at least 6 hours of sunlight daily for best results in blooming and sustaining health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Jacobaea vulgaris is mainly for managing its spread and appearance. Since ragwort can be invasive, removing faded flowers promptly can prevent excessive seeding. Deadhead regularly during its blooming period to maintain neatness and control its spread. Cut back dead or diseased stems immediately to encourage healthy growth and reduce pest risks. If managing large areas, mow plants before seed sets to prevent propagation. Wear gloves when handling to avoid skin irritation or allergic reactions due to the plant’s toxic properties."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"ragwort","description":"Jacobaea vulgaris, syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12505,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lupinus arizonicus, commonly known as the Arizona lupine, prefers well-drained soil and requires consistent watering, especially during its growing season. However, it is drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Aim to water in the early morning or late evening to reduce evaporation. In particularly dry climates or during hot spells, you may need to increase the frequency to keep the soil lightly moist but do not allow the plant to sit in standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lupinus arizonicus thrives in full sun conditions. It requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight every day to perform well, which aids in producing vibrant flowers and maintaining robust growth. If planted in partial shade, the plant may not bloom as profusely and could develop leggy or weak stems. Therefore, selecting a site with consistent sunlight exposure is crucial for optimal growth. In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from excessive heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lupinus arizonicus is not typically extensive. You should prune after the flowering season has ended to encourage new growth and manage its shape. Remove spent blooms (deadhead) to prevent the plant from using energy to produce seeds, which can also prolong its blooming period. Trim away any dead or yellowing foliage to maintain plant health and appearance. If the plant becomes leggy, a more substantial cut back can encourage a bushier form the following season. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arizona lupine","description":"Lupinus arizonicus (Arizona lupine) is a flowering plant in the family Fabaceae, native to the Mojave and Sonoran Deserts, where it can be found growing in open places and sandy washes below 1,100 metres (3,600 ft) elevation. It is common around Joshua Tree National Park and Death Valley National Park in California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Arizona lupine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Lupinus arizonicus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly","Dry","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the substrate or the growing medium remains damp but not waterlogged. It is critical to maintain the humidity levels around 85-90%. Misting the growing area periodically with water will help maintain moisture, but take care not to over-water, as this can lead to mold or other fungal issues. Using a hygrometer can aid in monitoring the moisture levels effectively. The goal is to mimic a natural forest floor environment, which is typically evenly moist but rarely saturated."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agaricus bitorquis is typically cultivated indoors or in controlled environments where direct sunlight is not advisable. These mushrooms thrive in low-light conditions, mimicking their natural habitat under forest canopies. Indirect light is sufficient for their growth. Fluorescent lamps or LED grow lights are commonly used to provide the necessary lighting conditions without overheating or drying out the growing space. Consistent temperatures and low light contribute to a successful yield, making the management of artificial lighting pivotal for indoor cultivation efforts."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not a conventional practice with Agaricus bitorquis, as it is with traditional garden plants. However, it's necessary to manage harvested mushrooms regularly to encourage ongoing production. When removing the mushrooms, carefully twist and pull them out of the substrate or use a clean knife to cut at the base, avoiding damage to the growing mycelium. Ensure old, decaying mushrooms are promptly removed to prevent contamination and the spread of disease. Keeping the growing environment tidy and free from expired growth will help maintain a healthy cycle for the mushrooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pavement Mushroom","description":"Agaricus bitorquis is an edible white mushroom of the genus Agaricus, similar to the common button mushroom that is sold commercially. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12306,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Triticum aestivum, commonly known as common wheat, requires consistent watering, especially during its growth phases. It prefers well-draining soil to prevent waterlogging, which can damage the roots. The key is to maintain evenly moist soil without letting it become too dry or too saturated. In the initial growth stages, water more frequently, ensuring the soil remains moist but not soaked. As the plant matures, reduce the frequency but allow deeper soil penetration for each watering. Monitor rainfall if grown outdoors, as too much or too little water can affect growth and yield."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Triticum aestivum thrives in full sunlight, ideally receiving at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. This plant is best suited to areas with long, sunny periods, which is crucial for its growth and development phases. Insufficient sunlight can lead to stunted growth and lower grain yield. Ensure that the planting location is in an open field or garden that is not shaded by buildings or trees for optimal sunlight exposure. Consistently good sunlight will promote healthy photosynthesis, contributing to strong growth and abundant production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically a requirement for Triticum aestivum as it is with some other plants. However, ensuring that dead or diseased tillers are removed can help maintain a healthy growth environment. This can also prevent the spread of disease. Ensuring the plant receives adequate sunlight will also support its overall health and pest resistance, making it a robust addition to a sunny garden setting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Arctostaphylos montana is generally only necessary to remove dead or diseased wood and to maintain its shape. This should be done after flowering to preserve the blooms. Use clean, sharp tools to make cuts just above a leaf node or lateral branch, being careful not to damage the main stem. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant. Light trimming can also encourage bushier growth. Regular inspection and selective pruning can help control the size and shape of the plant while maintaining its health and vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mount Tamalpais manzanita","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California"],"other_name":["Mount Tamalpais manzanita"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Arctostaphylos montana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12208,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lepidium draba, commonly known as hoary cress or whitetop, is a plant adapted to dry conditions. This perennial prefers well-draining soil and does not require frequent watering. It is drought-tolerant once established, so minimal irrigation is generally sufficient, especially in regions with regular rainfall. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot and other fungal diseases. During dry periods or extended droughts, you might consider occasional watering to maintain plant health, but ensure the soil dries out between waterings to prevent any waterlogging issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lepidium draba thrives in full sunlight, which encourages healthy growth and flowering. It can tolerate partial shade, but for optimal development and to reduce leggy or sparse growth, full sun exposure is preferred. The plant is hardy and can adapt to various light conditions, but ample sunlight supports robust and vigorous growth. If grown in areas with partial shade, you may notice reduced flowering and less compact growth. Therefore, selecting a location with at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day would be ideal for growing Lepidium draba successfully."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lepidium draba involves removing any dead, damaged, or diseased growth to promote healthy plant structure and prevent the spread of diseases. Ideally, provide it with filtered sunlight or morning sun with some afternoon shade. Adjust its location based on its response to the intensity of sunlight in your area."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex pauciflora is not often necessary, as it is a naturally low-growing sedge. However, to maintain a tidy appearance and promote healthy growth, you can periodically remove any dead or damaged leaves. This can be done in early spring before the new growth starts. Regularly inspect the plant to keep it healthy and well-maintained throughout its growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"few-flowered sedge","description":"Carex pauciflora, known as few-flowered sedge, is a perennial species of sedge in the family Cyperaceae native to Holarctic wetlands. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13205,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Juniperus grandis, like most junipers, thrives in well-drained soil and doesn’t require frequent watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it’s crucial to let the soil dry out between waterings. During the first year after planting, water regularly to establish a deep root system, especially in dry periods. Once established, Juniperus grandis is quite drought-tolerant and will do well with minimal supplemental watering, relying mainly on rainfall. In extremely hot, dry conditions, a deep watering once a month will help maintain its health and vigor."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Juniperus grandis thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of bright sunlight per day to maintain its dense foliage and healthy growth. Inadequate sunlight can lead to sparse growth and make the plant more susceptible to disease. While it can endure some light shade, full sun is preferred for optimal health and vitality. Planting in a location that provides ample direct sunlight ensures that the juniper maintains its form, color, and overall robustness. It's a hardy plant that can tolerate a range of environments, as long as sunlight requirements are met."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Juniperus grandis involves removing dead or diseased wood and occasionally thinning out branches to maintain its shape and encourage air circulation. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth starts. Avoid cutting into old wood, which may not regenerate, and instead focus on trimming the newest growth. Junipers generally require minimal pruning, so only do so to control size or to shape the plant according to aesthetic preferences. Avoid heavy pruning during the autumn to prevent leaving the plant susceptible to winter damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sierra juniper","description":"Juniperus grandis, with the common names Sierra juniper, Sierra western juniper, and western juniper, is a tree or tall shrub that is endemic to the Western United States. It is sometimes considered a variety of subspecies of Juniperus occidentalis, also known as the western juniper.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Dark blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Sierra juniper"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Juniperus grandis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12607,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Abies amabilis, commonly known as the Pacific Silver Fir, prefers consistent moisture in well-draining soil. During dry periods or droughts, provide supplemental watering to maintain soil moisture, especially in the early years of growth to establish strong roots. In contrast, reducing watering during the rainy season is recommended. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Abies amabilis grows best in full to partial shade conditions. It prefers a cooler, more humid environment, often found under the canopy of taller trees. While it can tolerate some sunlight, excessive direct sunlight can lead to stress and needle scorch. The tree will perform best in environments that provide dappled sunlight or filtered light through taller trees. Ensuring it receives adequate moisture is crucial if grown in sunnier spots, to mitigate potential heat stress. In its native habitat, it typically grows in moist, cool forest conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Abies amabilis should be done minimally as this tree naturally maintains an attractive shape. The best time for pruning is late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Light pruning can also be done to encourage denser foliage or shape the tree. Avoid heavy pruning, which can stress the tree and ruin its natural shape. Regularly remove any fallen needles or debris to promote airflow and reduce disease risk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pacific silver fir","description":"Abies amabilis, commonly known as the Pacific silver fir, is a fir native to the Pacific Northwest of North America, occurring in the Pacific Coast Ranges and the Cascade Range from the extreme southeast of Alaska, through western British Columbia, Washington and Oregon, to the extreme northwest of California. It is also commonly referred to as the white fir, red fir, lovely fir, Amabilis fir, Cascades fir, or silver fir. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12209,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Limonium californicum, commonly known as California sealavender, is a drought-tolerant plant, meaning it prefers well-drained soil and infrequent watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's essential to let the soil dry out completely between waterings. Generally, watering deeply once every two weeks during dry periods should suffice. If the plant is grown in a pot, ensure it has drainage holes to prevent waterlogging. Adjust your watering schedule based on your local climate and the time of year, reducing frequency during cooler months when the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Limonium californicum thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to perform its best. It is adapted to coastal environments but can also do well in inland gardens with sufficient sunlight. Providing full sun will encourage abundant blooming and compact growth. In areas with intense summer heat, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching. If grown indoors or in shaded areas, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers, as it stretches toward available light sources. An outdoor spot with unobstructed sunlight is ideal for robust growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Limonium californicum involves removing spent flowers and any dead or yellowing leaves. This maintenance should be done regularly to encourage new growth and prolong the flowering period. After the flowering season, cut back the flower stalks to their base to tidy up the plant's appearance. If the plant becomes too untidy, a light trim or shaping in the fall can help maintain its form. Avoid heavy pruning, as this plant doesn’t respond well to cutting back too much green growth. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Western Marsh Rosemary","description":"Limonium californicum is a species of sea lavender known by the common names western marsh rosemary and California sea lavender.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["Western Marsh Rosemary"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Limonium californicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10504,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Clarkia biloba, commonly known as the 'farewell to spring,' is a drought-tolerant plant that prefers infrequent watering. It's best to water it deeply but allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings, especially during its active growth period in spring and early summer. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot or ground has good drainage. During dormancy in the cooler months, reduce watering significantly, only enough to prevent the soil from becoming completely dry. Monitoring the soil moisture is crucial to maintain this plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clarkia biloba thrives in full sunlight, typically requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial shade, but this may result in fewer blooms. The plant’s flowering and overall growth are optimal when it receives abundant sunlight, mimicking its natural environment. When grown indoors, place it near a bright, south-facing window or use supplemental grow lights if necessary. If located in an excessively hot climate, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching, especially during the peak of summer."},{"type":"pruning","description":"To keep Clarkia biloba healthy and to encourage more branching, you should prune it regularly. Deadheading spent flowers will prolong its blooming period. Pruning should be done after the flowering season has ended; this helps in maintaining the plant's shape and encourages more vigorous growth. When pruning, remove any dead or diseased stems and cut back any excessively long shoots. This not only helps the plant maintain a neat appearance but also promotes air circulation, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"twolobe clarkia","description":"Clarkia biloba is a species of flowering plant in the evening primrose family known by the common name twolobe clarkia and two lobed clarkia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California"],"other_name":["twolobe clarkia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Whiteflies","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Clarkia biloba"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It may also be necessary to trim back the plant's tendrils and longer vines regularly to prevent it from becoming too invasive, especially if grown in a garden setting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hairy milkweed","description":"Sarcostemma hirtellum (Funastrum hirtellum) (rambling milkweed, hairy milkweed), is a perennial, vine-like plant of mid- to lower-elevation desert regions. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11604,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Agaricus arvensis, commonly known as the Horse Mushroom, thrives in moist environments. However, its watering needs are minimal as it typically grows in damp conditions naturally. If cultivating, maintain a consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. Water when the top layer of soil feels dry to the touch, ensuring that the substrate is able to drain excess moisture efficiently. Overwatering can lead to mushiness or rot, so it is crucial to strike a balance that keeps conditions humid yet aerated. Avoid letting the substrate completely dry out to ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"While Agaricus arvensis requires light, direct sunlight is not necessary for growth. Instead, this mushroom thrives in indirect light or shaded areas that mimic its natural habitat in grassy fields or woods where it often grows among decaying organic matter. Aim for a well-lit location that provides diffuse natural light or use artificial grow lights if cultivating indoors. Direct sunlight can lead to excessive drying or overheating, which could harm the delicate structures of the mushroom, so provide ample shade or indirect lighting conditions to optimize growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Agaricus arvensis mainly involves harvesting the mushrooms instead of traditional pruning, as it is a fungus. Once the cap has fully opened and before the gills start to darken, gently twist the stem to remove the mushrooms. It's important to avoid cutting with a knife to prevent soil contamination around the remaining fungi. Regular harvesting encourages the growth of more mushrooms. Maintain cleanliness in the growing area, removing any decomposed organic matter to prevent mold and other fungal pathogens from affecting healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Horse Mushroom","description":"Agaricus arvensis, commonly known as the horse mushroom, is a mushroom of the genus Agaricus.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Horse Mushroom"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Agaricus arvensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the first growing season, water the plant regularly to establish a deep rooting system. Afterward, it prefers dry conditions and should only be watered during extended periods of drought. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11903,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sedum obtusatum, commonly known as broadleaf stonecrop, prefers well-draining soil and does not require frequent watering. Water the plant thoroughly but allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, as sedums are drought-tolerant and store water in their leaves. During the growing season in spring and summer, you may water more often, but reduce watering in fall and winter. Ensure pots have drainage holes to prevent water accumulation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sedum obtusatum thrives in locations with full sun, receiving at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may cause leggy growth, reducing the plant's visual appeal and overall health. For optimal growth and flowering, place this plant in a sunny spot, such as a south or west-facing window if grown indoors, or an open garden bed where it can soak up ample sunlight outdoors. Ample sunlight also enhances the pigmentation of its leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sedum obtusatum typically involves removing dead or damaged stems to encourage new growth and maintain a tidy appearance. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13206,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Juniperus osteosperma, commonly known as Utah juniper, is well-adapted to arid environments and requires minimal watering. It is drought-tolerant once established, so overwatering should be avoided. Water deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth. During the first growing season, water weekly to establish a strong root system. After that, water only during extended dry spells or extreme heat, once every 2-4 weeks on average, ensuring the soil dries out between waterings. Ensure adequate drainage to prevent root rot, as this plant does not tolerate waterlogged conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Juniperus osteosperma thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun per day. It is adapted to withstand intense solar exposure typical of its native arid and semi-arid regions. Plant this juniper in a sunny location to ensure robust growth and development. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight can lead to leggy growth and affect its dense foliage. Ensuring ample sunlight exposure will also help in maintaining its characteristic compact and bushy appearance, contributing to a healthier plant overall."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Juniperus osteosperma is usually minimal. It's best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain its health and appearance. Avoid excessive pruning into old wood, as the plant may not produce new growth on these areas. Light shaping or thinning can be performed to control size and shape but should be done sparingly to preserve the plant's natural form. Always use sharp, clean pruning tools to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Utah Juniper","description":"Juniperus osteosperma (Utah juniper; syn. J. utahensis) is a shrub or small tree reaching 3–6 m (rarely to 9 m) tall. It is native to the southwestern United States, in Utah, Nevada, Arizona, western New Mexico, western Colorado, Wyoming, southern Montana, southern Idaho and eastern California. It grows at moderate altitudes of 1,300–2,600 metres (4,300–8,500 ft), on dry soils, often together with Pinus monophylla.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Utah Juniper"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Juniperus osteosperma"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If planted under too much shade, the plant might become leggier or may not spread as effectively. Removing any dead or damaged stems and leaves at this time can also promote healthy growth and reduce potential disease problems."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"rice cutgrass","description":"Leersia oryzoides is a species of grass known by the common name rice cutgrass or just cut-grass. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12808,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Camissoniopsis cheiranthifolia, commonly known as Beach Primrose, prefers dry conditions, so minimal watering is required. Once established, watering should be infrequent, allowing the soil to dry out between sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to err on the side of underwatering. In sandy soils or desert-like conditions, occasional watering during particularly hot, dry spells may be necessary, but generally, natural rainfall suffices. Container-grown plants may need more regular watering, but ensure pots have excellent drainage to prevent waterlogging. It's best to water deeply rather than frequent light waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Camissoniopsis cheiranthifolia thrives in full sun conditions, making it ideal for open landscapes with plenty of direct sunlight. It can tolerate partial shade but may produce fewer flowers and exhibit less vigorous growth in shadier conditions. The plant is well-suited to coastal and sandy habitats, where it benefits from unobstructed sunlight throughout the day. Ensure that it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal blooming and growth. In hotter inland areas, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent excessive heat stress, although the plant is resilient to harsh conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Camissoniopsis cheiranthifolia is not overly demanding, but occasional pruning helps maintain its appearance and encourage bushier growth. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased stems to promote plant health and minimize pest problems. Late winter or early spring is a good time for heavier pruning before new growth emerges. Trimming back leggy stems or spent flower stalks can help the plant maintain a more compact and tidy form. Drastic pruning is rarely necessary, but occasional tuning promotes vitality and encourages denser foliage. Use clean, sharp tools to minimize injury and the risk of spreading disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"beach suncup","description":"Camissoniopsis cheiranthifolia (beach suncup or beach evening primrose) is a species of the evening primrose family and is native to open dunes and sandy soils of coastal California and Oregon.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["beach suncup"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Camissoniopsis cheiranthifolia"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It does not tolerate drought well, so it is important to water it regularly, especially during dry spells. The soil should be kept evenly moist but not waterlogged, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. In general, watering once or twice a week should be sufficient, depending on the climate and soil drainage conditions. Ensure the top inch of the soil is allowed to dry out between waterings to prevent fungal issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rumex obtusifolius thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It is adaptable to various light conditions but prefers an environment with at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. However, it can tolerate partial shade especially in areas with intense sunlight, as some protection from the hottest afternoon sun can help prevent leaf scorch and maintain vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rumex obtusifolius is primarily about managing its growth and preventing it from becoming invasive, as it can spread rapidly. Regularly remove the flower stalks before they set seed to control the plant's spread. Cut back dead or damaged leaves to encourage new growth and maintain a tidier appearance. In late autumn, you can cut back the entire plant to ground level to prepare for the following growing season. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"broad-leaved dock","description":"Rumex obtusifolius, commonly known as bitter dock, broad-leaved dock, bluntleaf dock, dock leaf or butter dock, is a perennial weed in the family Polygonaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12608,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Abies lasiocarpa, commonly known as Subalpine Fir, requires consistent watering, especially during the dry months. It is essential to keep the soil moist but not waterlogged. In its native environment, Abies lasiocarpa benefits from regular snowmelt and rainfall, so under artificial conditions, mimicking this by watering thoroughly once the topsoil feels dry is beneficial. Deep watering helps the roots grow deeper into the soil, improving the tree's overall resilience and health. Reducing watering frequency during the late fall and winter can prevent root rot and other moisture-related issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Abies lasiocarpa thrives in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates. In its natural habitat, it often grows in high-altitude environments where it receives ample sunlight. To support healthy growth, position the tree where it can enjoy at least six hours of sunlight per day. In areas with extremely hot conditions, providing some afternoon shade can prevent needle scorch and stress. While it can grow in partial shade, ensuring sufficient light exposure will help maintain its dense, compact growth and overall health, making it more resilient to pests and diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Abies lasiocarpa is generally minimal and should be conducted with care to maintain its natural shape. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to promote healthy growth and improve air circulation. It’s important not to over-prune as this can stress the tree or lead to undesirable growth patterns. Avoid cutting back to older wood that lacks green needles as this can inhibit new growth. Pruning should be focused on enhancing the tree's natural aesthetics and maintaining its health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"subalpine fir","description":"Abies lasiocarpa, commonly called the subalpine fir or Rocky Mountain fir, is a western North American fir tree.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western North America"],"other_name":["subalpine fir"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Abies lasiocarpa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13405,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pectis papposa, commonly known as lemonweed or chinchweed, is a drought-tolerant plant that thrives in arid environments. When grown in a garden setting, it should be watered sparingly. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, which is detrimental to the plant's health. It's best to mimic its natural desert habitat by providing minimal water, especially during the cooler seasons. During periods of active growth, such as late spring and early summer, a bit more water might be needed but always prioritize dry conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pectis papposa thrives in full sun, similar to its native desert environment. It requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day to perform optimally and produce its characteristic aromatic foliage and bright yellow flowers. Plant it in a location with unobstructed sunlight such as a south-facing garden bed or a sunny spot in your yard. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering, so ensure it receives ample sunlight for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pectis papposa isn't usually necessary for its health, but occasional trimming can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Prune in the early spring before new growth begins, removing any dead or damaged stems, and lightly shaping the plant if needed. Be careful not to remove too much foliage at once, as this can stress the plant. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can also encourage more blooms over the growing season. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make cuts to prevent any disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Chinchweed","description":"Pectis papposa is species of flowering plant in the aster family, Asteraceae. It is native to North America, where it occurs in the southwestern United States as far east as Texas, and in northern Mexico. Common names include cinchweed, common chinchweed, many-bristle chinchweed, and many-bristle fetid-marigold.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Chinchweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Pectis papposa"],"soil":["Dry","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
