{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13505,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Potamogeton natans, commonly known as floating pondweed, is an aquatic plant that thrives in a range of water conditions. It typically requires a consistent water environment, meaning the surrounding water should be stagnant or slow-moving. As an aquatic species, it naturally absorbs water through its leaves and roots, so there's no need for traditional watering. Instead, ensure the plant is submerged and the water level in the pond or container remains stable. If growing in an aquarium, regular water changes are essential to maintain water quality without introducing pollutants that might harm the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Potamogeton natans prefers a location with plenty of sunlight as it thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. The plant should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily. If placed in a pond or aquarium, ensure that it is not overly shaded by other vegetation or structures, as insufficient light can lead to poor growth and pale leaves. In an indoor setting, such as an aquarium, using artificial lights that mimic sunlight can provide the necessary illumination for optimal growth. It's important to strike a balance to avoid excessively high temperatures due to prolonged exposure to intense sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Potamogeton natans is generally minimal but necessary for maintaining water quality and aesthetic appeal. Remove dead or dying leaves regularly to prevent them from decaying and polluting the water. You can prune the plant during the growing season to control its growth and spread, especially if it's overshadowing other aquatic plants. Trimming is best done with sharp scissors or garden snips at the base of the stems or just above the node where new offshoots are forming. Regular pruning also promotes healthier growth and helps the plant direct energy to new, healthy leaves."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"floating-leaved pondweed","description":"Potamogeton natans (broad-leaved pondweed, floating pondweed, floating-leaf pondweed) is an aquatic species in the genus Potamogeton native to quiet or slow-flowing freshwater habitats throughout the Holarctic Kingdom.","family":null,"flower_color":"Brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["floating-leaved pondweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Potamogeton natans"],"soil":["Aquatic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12103,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Boletus rubellus, commonly known as the ruby bolete, thrives in moist environments typically found in nature. If cultivating in controlled environments, ensure that the substrate remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. Over-watering can lead to undesirable growth conditions and may promote mold or other fungi competitors. Regular misting or installing a humidifier can help maintain necessary humidity levels, especially in indoor settings. Monitoring the substrate's moisture content is crucial to ensure optimal growth conditions for this species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Boletus rubellus prefers dappled or indirect sunlight reflecting its natural habitat of deciduous woodland areas. Direct, intense sunlight can dry out the substrate and affect humidity levels essential for growth. Mimicking a forest canopy environment, with some filtered light, will yield the best results. For indoor cultivation, ensuring the growing area receives adequate indirect light without exposing the mushrooms to hot, direct sunlight can recreate the favorable conditions found under leaf litter in their natural habitats."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically required for Boletus rubellus as it is a type of wild mushroom. However, when harvesting, it is important to gently twist and pull mature mushrooms from the substrate to avoid damaging the mycelium network in the growth medium. Avoid cutting with a knife or tools that may leave residual parts of the mushroom that can rot or become infected. Proper and careful harvesting encourages sustainable and repeated mushroom growth in the same area."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Ruby bolete","description":"Hortiboletus rubellus, commonly known as the ruby bolete, is a small, dainty, brightly coloured member of the family Boletaceae, with a reddish cap and stipe, and yellow pores. Like many boletes, it stains blue when cut or bruised. It is found in deciduous woodland in autumn. There is some question over its edibility, and it is reportedly of poor quality with a taste of soap. Until 2015, the species was known as Boletus rubellus.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Ruby bolete"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Boletus rubellus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13305,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mammillaria grahamii, also known as Graham's nipple cactus, requires careful watering to prevent root rot. During the growing season, which is typically spring through early autumn, water the plant every two to three weeks, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. In the winter, reduce watering significantly, as the plant enters dormancy and requires very little moisture. Overwatering can lead to fungal infections and root rot, so ensure the pot has drainage holes and use well-draining cactus soil to promote healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mammillaria grahamii thrives under bright, indirect sunlight, but can also handle some direct sunlight, especially during the morning or late afternoon. Aim to provide at least 6 hours of such light per day to encourage healthy growth and blooming. If kept indoors, a south or east-facing window is ideal to meet its light needs. Too much direct sun in peak hours, especially in hot climates, can cause sunburn, while too little light can hamper growth and flowering. Adjust the plant's position if you notice these signs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Mammillaria grahamii is generally not necessary, but occasional maintenance can help keep the plant healthy and attractive. It's crucial to use a well-draining soil mix, ideally designed for cacti and succulents, to facilitate proper drainage and avoid water accumulation around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sedum oreganum thrives in bright sunlight and should receive full sun for at least six hours a day to maintain its vibrant color and compact growth. If grown indoors, a bright windowsill is recommended. Gradually introduce plants to full sun if they're not used to it, to prevent sunburn, especially during the summer months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sedum oreganum is generally minimal, as the plant maintains a tidy growth habit. However, it benefits from occasional trimming to remove dead or damaged leaves and stems, which encourages healthy new growth. It's best to prune in early spring before the plant's active growing season begins. Use clean, sharp scissors to make precise cuts, and trim back any leggy or overgrown stems to maintain a compact shape. Regular pruning helps prevent overcrowding and supports a healthier, more aesthetically pleasing plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Oregon Stonecrop","description":"Sedum oreganum is a species of succulent plant of the genus Sedum. While it can tolerate light shade, the plant's productivity and overall health can be compromised if sunlight is significantly reduced. Hence, choosing a bright, open location for planting is recommended to allow this legume to thrive and maintain vibrant, attractive foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Onobrychis viciifolia should be minimal. Due to its anthelmintic properties the common sainfoin is a natural alternative to drugs to control nematode parasitism in the guts of small ruminants. This is the main reason why O. viciifolia came back to the scientific agenda during the...","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Sainfoin"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Onobrychis viciifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Chalky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Consider the local climate when choosing the planting location, opting for more sunlight in cooler regions and some afternoon shade in warmer areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Galium boreale is fairly minimal and mostly involves cleaning up the plant. During the growing season, inspect the plant regularly and remove any dead, damaged, or yellowing leaves to maintain its appearance and health. In late fall or early spring, cut back any remaining dead vegetation to the ground to prepare for new growth. This will encourage a tidy appearance and robust growth during the subsequent growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Northern Bedstraw","description":"Galium boreale or northern bedstraw is a plant species of the Rubiaceae. Over-watering is a common mistake, so it's important to ensure the cactus is never sitting in water, as this can lead to root rot and other issues."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This species of cactus thrives in bright, direct sunlight and should be placed in a location where it can receive full sun for most of the day. If it's not acclimated to strong sunlight, gradually increase light exposure to prevent sunburn. In low-light conditions, the cactus may become etiolated, elongating and losing its characteristic dense, compact form."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for Mammillaria tetrancistra, as it grows in a compact manner. However, you can remove any dead or damaged spines when needed to maintain its appearance. Use sterile pruning shears or tweezers to gently clip away any dead material. If the cactus produces offsets, these can be removed to encourage cleaner growth and to propagate new plants. Always be cautious of the spines when handling the plant to prevent injury. Generally, this cactus does not require frequent pruning and should be left to grow naturally."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Common Fishhook Cactus","description":"Mammillaria tetrancistra is a species of fishhook cactus known by the common name common fishhook cactus. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12410,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sarcobatus vermiculatus, commonly known as greasewood, is highly drought-tolerant and thrives in arid environments. It typically doesn't require much additional watering, especially if it's receiving any natural rainfall. In regions where rainfall is scarce, provide deep waterings infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out completely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot or other moisture-related diseases. It's essential to ensure that the soil has good drainage to avoid water accumulation around the roots. Once established, greasewood is extremely resilient and can survive in very dry conditions without supplemental watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sarcobatus vermiculatus thrives in full sun environments. It requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day to grow optimally. This plant is native to arid regions and is well-adapted to intense sunlight. Placing it in a location that receives plenty of sun will ensure it remains healthy and robust. If planted in a partially shaded area, it might grow more slowly and produce fewer branches or flowers. While it can tolerate some shade, its natural habitat favors open, sunny spaces where it can get uninterrupted access to sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Sarcobatus vermiculatus can be done to maintain shape or control the size of the plant. It is best to prune in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and plant health. Since this plant has spiny branches, wear protective gloves during pruning. To promote bushy growth, trim back more vigorous shoots selectively. However, be cautious not to over-prune, as this could stress the plant. Frequent pruning is generally not necessary, as greasewood is a slow-growing plant that naturally maintains its form."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Greasewood","description":"Sarcobatus, is a North American genus of two species of flowering plants, formerly considered to be a single species. Common names for S. vermiculatus include greasewood, seepwood, and saltbush. Traditionally, Sarcobatus has been treated in the family Chenopodiaceae, but the APG III system of 2009 recognizes it as the sole genus in the family Sarcobataceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Greasewood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Sarcobatus vermiculatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Saline","Alkaline"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12310,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Galium nuttallii should be watered regularly during dry periods, particularly in its first year as it establishes roots. As the plant matures, it will tolerate some drought, but regular watering will promote healthier growth and more robust flowering in the growing season."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Galium nuttallii thrives in a location where it receives full sun to partial shade. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12610,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Abronia maritima, commonly known as red sand-verbena, prefers well-draining soil and requires moderate watering. Ensure the soil is dry between waterings to prevent root rot, as this plant is somewhat drought-tolerant. Watering deeply but less frequently will encourage deep root growth, enhancing its drought resistance. During particularly hot or dry periods, increase the frequency of watering but continue to allow the soil to dry out between sessions. Avoid overwatering, especially if planted in containers, as excess water can lead to poor plant health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Abronia maritima thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. This coastal native is accustomed to bright, open environments, making a sunny location ideal for its growth. In areas with extremely hot climates, some light afternoon shade might be beneficial to protect the plant from intense heat. However, insufficient sunlight can lead to poor flowering and spindly growth. When situating the plant, consider its natural preference for sunny, sandy coastal habitats to mimic its ideal growing conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Abronia maritima is not particularly necessary, but occasional trimming can help maintain its shape and health. Remove any dead or damaged stems to promote better air circulation and prevent disease. Trimming spent flowers can encourage longer blooming periods and keep the plant looking tidy. If the plant becomes too leggy or unwieldy, cut back a portion of the longest stems to encourage bushier growth. Pruning is best done in the growing season, typically spring through early summer, to minimize stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"red sand-verbena","description":"Abronia maritima is a species of sand verbena known by the common name red sand verbena. This is a beach-adapted perennial plant native to the coastlines of southern California, including the Channel Islands, and northern Baja California. It grows along stable sand dunes near, but not in, the ocean surf.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Mexico"],"other_name":["red sand-verbena"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Abronia maritima"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13706,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tragopogon pratensis, commonly known as Meadow Salsify or Jack-go-to-bed-at-noon, prefers moderately moist soil conditions. It's important to water this plant regularly during the growing season, ensuring that the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. In dry periods, increase watering frequency, but allow the topsoil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. During the dormant winter months, reduce watering. A good rule of thumb is to water when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Always use well-draining soil to prevent water accumulation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tragopogon pratensis thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. In its natural habitat, this plant is accustomed to open, sunny meadows and fields, and replicating these conditions will support healthy growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight may result in fewer flowers and taller, leggier growth. Ideally, plant it in a spot where it receives morning sun to encourage robust flowering and to help ensure the plant's characteristic behavior of closing its flowers by midday—hence its common name, “Jack-go-to-bed-at-noon.”"},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tragopogon pratensis involves removing dead or yellowing leaves, as well as spent flower stalks to encourage a tidy appearance and prevent self-seeding, as this plant can self-seed prolifically. After the blooming period, which usually ends in late summer, you should deadhead the flower stalks by cutting them back close to the base. Regular deadheading not only promotes a neat garden but also encourages a longer blooming period and prevents excessive seed dispersal. It's also helpful to trim any foliage that looks unhealthy to prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"meadow salsify","description":"Tragopogon pratensis (common names Jack-go-to-bed-at-noon, meadow salsify, showy goat's-beard or meadow goat's-beard) is a biennial plant in the Asteraceae family, distributed across Europe and North America, commonly growing in fields (hence its name) and on roadsides. It is found in North America from southern Ontario to Massachusetts; most of England; on the eastern and southern edges of Scotland; and central Ireland but not the coastal edges.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["meadow salsify"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Tragopogon pratensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12311,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Symphyotrichum subulatum, commonly known as annual saltmarsh aster, prefers moderately moist to slightly dry conditions. It's important to not let the soil dry out completely, especially during hotter periods when the plant is actively growing. However, avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry. During cooler months or when the plant is dormant, reduce the frequency of watering. Ensure that the planting site or container has good drainage to prevent water from pooling at the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Symphyotrichum subulatum thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth and flowering, provide at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. The plant is adaptable and can tolerate some shade, but this might result in fewer flowers and leggier growth. If you're growing the plant indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window, where it can receive ample light. In case of insufficient natural light, consider using grow lights to supplement. Adequate sunlight not only promotes healthy growth but also enhances the plant's overall vigor and resistance to disease."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Symphyotrichum subulatum helps promote bushier growth and more abundant flowering. Regularly deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming throughout the growing season. In early spring, perform a light trim to remove any dead or damaged stems from the previous year. This will help rejuvenate the plant and stimulate new growth. Avoid heavy pruning during late fall or winter as this can stress the plant. Pruning is generally straightforward and can be achieved with simple garden shears, focusing on cutting down to healthy outward-facing buds or nodes."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"annual saltmarsh aster","description":"Symphyotrichum subulatum (eastern annual saltmarsh aster or, in Britain and Ireland where it is naturalized, just annual saltmarsh aster) is an annual California desert plant in the sunflower family Asteraceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central America","North America"],"other_name":["annual saltmarsh aster"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Symphyotrichum subulatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid letting the soil dry out completely, but also avoid waterlogged conditions as this can damage the roots of the host plant and indirectly affect Kopsiopsis hookeri. Adjust the amount of light it receives depending on seasonal changes, ensuring consistent and stable light conditions for optimal growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Kopsiopsis hookeri involves maintaining the host plant and allowing space for the parasitic plant to thrive. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13707,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trautvetteria caroliniensis, commonly known as false bugbane or tassel-rue, prefers consistently moist soil conditions. It thrives in moist, well-drained environments and doesn't tolerate drying out. Water it regularly to keep the soil damp, especially during dry periods or the growing season. Overly wet soil due to poor drainage can lead to root rot, so ensure that the plant does not sit in waterlogged conditions. While it can tolerate brief dry spells once established, maintaining even moisture will support optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trautvetteria caroliniensis thrives best in partial to full shade, making it suitable for woodland garden settings. In its natural habitat, it often grows in shaded, wooded areas where it receives dappled sunlight. Excessive direct sunlight, especially during the hottest parts of the day, can lead to leaf scorch and stress the plant. Ideal growing conditions include filtered sunlight or morning sun with afternoon shade. Providing the plant with shade helps maintain the moisture it requires and keeps it healthy and vibrant throughout its growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Trautvetteria caroliniensis is generally minimal but beneficial for plant health and aesthetics. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage further blooming and keep the plant looking tidy. In fall or early spring, prune back any dead or damaged foliage to promote fresh, vigorous growth. Be cautious not to cut back too severely, as this can stress the plant. Pruning spent flowers can also help prevent unwanted self-seeding if this is a concern in garden management. Regularly removing any diseased or damaged parts will help maintain health and vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Carolina bugbane","description":"Trautvetteria is a genus of flowering plants in the buttercup family. Today it is often considered a monotypic genus, containing only one species, Trautvetteria caroliniensis, which is known by the common names Carolina bugbane, false bugbane, and tassel-rue. A second species, T. japonica, is now generally considered a variety of this species. The genus is named for the botanist Ernst Rudolf von Trautvetter.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Carolina bugbane"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Trautvetteria caroliniensis"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Monitoring the lighting conditions and adjusting as needed will ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Galium stellatum is generally minimal, as it tends to have a compact growth habit. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to make precise cuts and minimize any damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"starry bedstraw","description":"Galium stellatum (starry bedstraw or desert bedstraw) is a species of plant in the Rubiaceae family. During the first couple of years after planting, ensure it receives regular water, especially during dry spells, to help establish the root system."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This pine species thrives in full sun conditions, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Aleppo Pine is highly adaptable to different light conditions but performs best with abundant sunlight, which supports healthy growth and a strong structure. In shaded environments, it may grow more slowly and become sparse, affecting its characteristic shape. Therefore, ensure your Aleppo Pine is planted in a location where it receives ample sunlight, as insufficient light can lead to weak growth and poor overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Pinus halepensis primarily to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. This should be done during the winter when the tree is dormant. Remove branches that cross or grow inward to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. Pinching back new growth can help maintain a more compact shape if desired. Avoid heavy pruning as pines do not recover well from excessive cuts. Maintaining its natural form is generally recommended, as Aleppo Pine has an open and irregular crown that gives it its distinct appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Aleppo pine","description":"Pinus halepensis, commonly known as the Aleppo pine, is a pine native to the Mediterranean region. Its range extends from Morocco, Algeria and Spain north to southern France, Italy, Croatia, Montenegro, Albania, and east to Greece, all over Malta and northern Tunisia, with an outlying population (from which it was first described) in Syria, Lebanon, southern Turkey, Jordan, Israel, and Palestinian territories. In Israel it is called Jerusalem pine.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean Basin"],"other_name":["Aleppo pine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pinus halepensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10902,"attracts":["Birds","Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carya cordiformis, commonly known as bitternut hickory, prefers well-drained soil but can tolerate different moisture levels. During prolonged dry spells, provide additional water to prevent stress, but be cautious to avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot. Established trees typically handle natural rainfall well and need minimal supplemental watering. Use mulch to retain soil moisture and reduce evaporation. Always check the soil for moisture before watering, making sure the top few inches are dry before adding more water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carya cordiformis thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth, provide the tree with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate partial shade, but full sun will assure better growth rates, stronger branches, and more robust health. When planting, choose a location that allows the tree to capture as much sunlight as possible while considering future growth and potential shading from nearby structures or larger trees. Adequate sunlight is vital for photosynthesis and overall vigor, leading to an attractive tree with a strong, well-formed structure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carya cordiformis should generally be done during the dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain the plant’s health and structure. For young trees, focus on developing a strong central leader and remove any competing branches. Avoid heavy pruning, as hickories naturally have a pleasing shape and structure. It's also important to remove any crossing or rubbing branches to prevent further damage. Prune sparingly to maintain natural form while ensuring good air circulation within the canopy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bitternut hickory","description":"Carya cordiformis, the bitternut hickory, also called bitternut or swamp hickory, is a large pecan hickory with commercial stands located mostly north of the other pecan hickories. Bitternut hickory is cut and sold in mixture with the true hickories. It is the shortest-lived of the hickories, living to about 200 years.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["bitternut hickory"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Hickory Shoot Canker","Hickory Bark Beetle"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Carya cordiformis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid heavy pruning as the plant’s natural growth habit is best left somewhat undisturbed for optimal flowering next season. Regularly clearing spent flowers can encourage healthier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"largeflower fairybells","description":"Prosartes smithii is a North American species of flowering plants known by the common name largeflower fairybells. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11103,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rosa canina, commonly known as the dog rose, requires moderate watering. It is best to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season, water the plant thoroughly once a week, ensuring that the water reaches the deepest roots. However, in hot and dry weather, you may need to increase the frequency to twice a week. It's important to use well-drained soil and provide water early in the day to allow excess moisture to evaporate, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rosa canina thrives best in full sun conditions, which means it requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, optimal blooming and growth occur with ample sunlight. Plant it in a location where it won’t be overshadowed by larger plants or structures. Adequate sunlight helps to reduce disease occurrence by allowing the plant to dry off more quickly after rain or dew, thereby creating a less favorable environment for fungal diseases such as powdery mildew or black spot."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rosa canina is crucial for maintaining its health and shape. It's best to prune in late winter or early spring while the plant is still dormant. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to enhance air circulation and light penetration. Cut back about a third of the older stems to encourage new growth. Additionally, trim the plant to maintain its desired shape, but avoid drastic cuts. Regular deadheading during the blooming season can also promote continued flowering and neat appearance. Use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dog-rose","description":"Rosa canina, commonly known as the dog rose, is a variable climbing, wild rose species native to Europe, northwest Africa, and western Asia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North Africa","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Dog-rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rosa canina"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Its odor is considered similar to that of the bergamot orange (the source of bergamot oil used to flavor Earl Grey tea). The scientific name comes from Nicolas Monardes, who described the first American flora in 1569.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Scarlet Beebalm"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Monarda didyma"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Once the flowers have bloomed and started to die back, deadheading is advised to prevent self-seeding and promote a tidier appearance. Cut the spent blooms down to the base as they fade. Clean up dead leaves and plant debris to avoid disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"European Pasqueflower","description":"Pulsatilla vulgaris (pasque flower, pasqueflower, common pasque flower, European pasqueflower, Dane's blood) is a species of flowering plant belonging to the buttercup family (Ranunculaceae), found locally on calcareous grassland in Europe. While it can tolerate some shade, full sun exposure results in more profuse flowering and vigorous growth. When planted in a location that receives morning sun and afternoon shade, the plant can grow successfully, but for optimal blooming, aim for at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. Ensure proper airflow around the plant to avoid mildew problems often associated with shaded, humid conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lonicera periclymenum is essential to maintain its shape, beauty, and encourage vigorous growth. To control its size and shape, cut back some of the older, longer stems to a healthy bud. After flowering, you can also lightly trim to shape and promote a compact form. It prefers well-draining soil and doesn't tolerate waterlogged conditions, so it's important to ensure good drainage to avoid bulb rot. During the dormant period in the summer, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out almost completely between waterings, as the plant naturally experiences a dry period in its native habitats. Indoors, a south or west-facing window can work well for providing ample light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning isn't a major requirement for Calochortus venustus. However, it is beneficial to remove spent flowers to prevent seed formation and channel the plant’s energy back to the bulb. This can also help maintain a tidier appearance. Pruning should be minimal and primarily focused on maintaining plant health and cleanliness."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Butterfly Mariposa Lily","description":"Calochortus venustus is a California species of flowering plants in the lily family known by the common name butterfly mariposa lily.","family":null,"flower_color":"White, Pink, Yellow, Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","Western North America"],"other_name":["Butterfly Mariposa Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb Division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Calochortus venustus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10602,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vaccinium fuscatum, commonly known as black highbush blueberry, prefers consistently moist, well-drained soils. Water the plant regularly during the first growing season to establish a deep, extensive root system. Once established, it requires watering during dry, hot spells in the summer. Avoid waterlogging the roots, as this can lead to root rot. Applying a mulch layer helps retain soil moisture and reduce watering frequency. Always ensure the soil is moist but not soggy; overwatering can be as damaging as under-watering. In drier climates, drip irrigation or soaker hoses can be beneficial for maintaining moisture levels."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vaccinium fuscatum thrives in full sun to partial shade. Full sunlight (at least 6 hours per day) is optimal for flower and fruit production, leading to more robust yields. However, the plant can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, where some afternoon shade can prevent scorching and stress. In shaded locations, expect fewer, smaller berries. Maintaining a balance between sunlight exposure and shelter from extreme afternoon heat will promote the healthiest growth and fruit production. Consider the sun pattern in your planting area and the plant's position relative to other structures or trees that may cast shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vaccinium fuscatum should be done during its dormant season, typically late winter. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged wood to promote healthy growth. Open up the center of the bush by cutting away crossing branches to improve air circulation. This also allows sunlight to penetrate the plant, encouraging fruit production. Younger shrubs require little pruning, mostly focusing on shaping and maintaining desired size. For mature plants, cut back one-third of the oldest branches annually to spur new growth. This method helps sustain vigor and ensures consistent fruiting from season to season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Black Highbush Blueberry","description":"Vaccinium fuscatum, commonly called black highbush blueberry, is a species of flowering plant in the heath family (Ericaceae). It is native eastern to North America, where it is found in Canada and the United States. Its typical natural habitat is wet areas such as bogs, pocosins, and swamps.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Black Highbush Blueberry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Vaccinium fuscatum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11600,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Chlorophyllum brunneum, commonly known as the Brown Parasol mushroom, does not require watering like typical houseplants as it thrives outdoors in natural environments. It typically grows in well-drained soils that are rich in organic matter, so maintaining these conditions naturally with rainfall is usually adequate. If cultivating outdoors, ensure that the soil stays slightly moist, especially during dry periods, but avoid waterlogging as this can encourage rot and fungal diseases. Adding organic mulch can help maintain soil moisture. If growing indoors or in a controlled setting, a light misting to maintain humidity can simulate outdoor conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Chlorophyllum brunneum does not require direct sunlight as it is a type of mushroom. Instead, it thrives in shaded areas with indirect light. It typically grows in environments with dappled light, such as under trees or in the forest where it benefits from the filtered sunlight. In a cultivated setting, you should mimic these conditions by placing it in an area where it receives indirect sunlight or dappled shade. Managing light exposure is crucial as too much direct sunlight can dry out the environment, hindering its growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Chlorophyllum brunneum, as it is a mushroom and does not have parts that require cutting back like leaves or branches in plant care. However, it is beneficial to remove any old or decomposing mushrooms promptly to maintain a healthy environment and prevent the spread of mold and pests. Regularly inspect the growing area and carefully pick mature mushrooms to encourage more growth and prevent decay, ensuring you handle the fungi gently to avoid damaging the mycelium network essential for their reproduction."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Shaggy Parasol","description":"The Shaggy parasol is the common name for three closely related species of mushroom, Chlorophyllum rhacodes (or rachodes), C. olivieri and C. brunneum, found in North America, Europe and Southern Africa (the latter species is also found in Australia).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Shaggy Parasol"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Chlorophyllum brunneum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, especially during its growth period in spring and summer. The plant can tolerate some drought once it's established, but ideally, the top inch of soil should be kept moist. Reduce the frequency of watering during the fall and winter months as the plant enters a dormant phase. Ensure the pot or growing area has good drainage to prevent root rot, which can occur if the plant sits in water for too long."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Clinopodium douglasii thrives in partial to full sun conditions. It grows best when it receives about 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching and help maintain the plant's health. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. In lower light conditions, the plant may become leggy or produce fewer flowers, so adjusting its positioning to ensure adequate sunlight can help it thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Clinopodium douglasii is generally not necessary for its health, but occasional trimming can promote bushier growth and maintain its shape. If the plant becomes leggy or overgrown, you can trim back the stems by one-third in the early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or diseased foliage to encourage healthy development. Light pruning throughout its growing season can help direct energy towards more vigorous branches and a fuller appearance. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent any disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"yerba buena","description":"Clinopodium douglasii, or yerba buena, is a rambling aromatic herb of western and northwestern North America, ranging from maritime Alaska southwards to California. The plant takes the form of a sprawling, mat-forming perennial, and is especially abundant close to the coast. The name \"yerba buena\" derives from Spanish for \"good herb\" and is applied to various other plants. Molecular evidence places the species within the Clinopodium complex rather than Micromeria.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Western North America"],"other_name":["yerba buena"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Clinopodium douglasii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12106,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spiraea douglasii prefers consistently moist soil but can tolerate short periods of drought once established. During the growing season, water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil is evenly moist but not waterlogged. It's best to water deeply and infrequently rather than little and often, promoting strong root development. In hotter climates or during extended dry spells, more frequent watering may be necessary, especially if the plant shows signs of stress such as wilting. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture. Reduce watering during the winter months when the plant is dormant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spiraea douglasii thrives in full sun to part shade. For optimal flowering and growth, it is best to provide a location with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may result in fewer blooms and a leggier growth habit. In very hot or dry climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and reduce water stress. Adequate sunlight ensures lush foliage and vibrant flowering, making it important to select a planting spot that balances light and heat exposure according to your region's conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Spiraea douglasii is crucial to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches, cutting them back to healthy tissue. To manage size and encourage bushiness, prune the previous year's growth back by about one-third. You can also cut the oldest stems down to the base to stimulate new shoots, improving the plant's appearance. After flowering, light pruning can help maintain a tidy shape. Regular pruning will result in a more vigorous and floriferous plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Rose Spirea","description":"Spiraea douglasii is a species of flowering plant in the rose family native to western North America. Common names include hardhack, hardhack steeplebush, Douglas' spirea, douglasspirea, steeplebush, and rose spirea.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Rose Spirea"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Spiraea douglasii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Be cautious of root rot, particularly if grown in poorly draining soil or containers without adequate drainage holes. It can tolerate a wide range of light conditions but generally prefers a sunny environment for optimal growth and flowering. In regions with very hot summers, providing some afternoon shade might prevent stress and wilting. This plant is adaptable and can also grow fairly well in partial shade, although it might not flower as vigorously as it would under full sun. Ensure it gets at least 6 hours of sunlight daily for best results in blooming and sustaining health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Jacobaea vulgaris is mainly for managing its spread and appearance. Since ragwort can be invasive, removing faded flowers promptly can prevent excessive seeding. Deadhead regularly during its blooming period to maintain neatness and control its spread. Wear gloves when handling to avoid skin irritation or allergic reactions due to the plant’s toxic properties."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"ragwort","description":"Jacobaea vulgaris, syn. It prefers dry climates and can withstand minimal irrigation, making it suitable for xeriscaping. Water the plant sparingly and ensure the soil dries out between waterings. Over-watering could lead to root rot, so it’s crucial to avoid water-logged conditions. During dry spells, once every two weeks should suffice, while even less is required during seasonal rains or damp weather."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Castilleja subinclusa thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. It performs best when receiving direct sunlight for most of the day, which helps promote vibrant blooms. However, in regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent overheating and stress. If grown in partial shade, ensure that the plant receives at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily. Insufficient sunlight may lead to fewer flowers and leggy growth. Thus, position the plant where it can bask in sunlight for optimal health and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Castilleja subinclusa is minimal but beneficial for maintaining a healthy appearance and encouraging bountiful blooming. Remove dead or damaged stems and spent flowers to prevent disease and promote more vigorous growth. The best time to prune is after the last frost in early spring or after the flowering season in late summer. Use clean, sharp tools to make neat cuts and avoid cutting into the older woody stems as this could harm the plant. Regular pruning helps keep the plant tidy and may enhance its natural shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Longleaf paintbrush","description":"Castilleja subinclusa is a species of Indian paintbrush known by the common names longleaf Indian paintbrush and Franciscan Paint Brush.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Longleaf paintbrush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Castilleja subinclusa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11504,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Herniaria hirsuta, commonly known as hairy rupturewort, thrives in well-drained soil and requires infrequent watering once established. During its active growing season in spring and early summer, it benefits from moderate watering to maintain slight soil moisture without becoming soggy. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to avoid root rot. In winter or dormant periods, significantly reduce watering, allowing for some dryness, as the plant is tolerant to drought conditions. Always consider the specific environmental conditions, adjusting frequency as necessary to prevent overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Herniaria hirsuta prefers full sun to partial shade conditions. To ensure optimal growth and a compact form, provide the plant with at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In areas with particularly hot or intense afternoon sun, some light afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. In regions with cooler climates, full sun exposure is best to encourage robust growth. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced vitality. Adjust the plant's placement if it appears to be stretching or losing its vibrant condition due to inadequate light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Herniaria hirsuta is generally not necessary as the plant maintains a low-growing, compact form. However, light trimming can be performed to control its spread or remove any dead or damaged stems, which can help maintain its neat appearance. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth emerges. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make cuts just above a node. Avoid heavy pruning as this plant is slow-growing and excessive cutting could stress it unnecessarily. Occasional light grooming will keep it healthy and vigorous."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"hairy rupturewort","description":"Herniaria hirsuta is a species of flowering plant in the pink family known by the common name hairy rupturewort. It is native to Eurasia and North Africa, and it is known on other continents, including North America, as an introduced species. This is an annual herb with stems up to 20 cm (8 in) long usually growing prostrate along the ground. The small, fuzzy, pale green leaves are up to about a centimeter long and coat the stems....","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["hairy rupturewort"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Herniaria hirsuta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12206,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phalaris arundinacea, commonly known as reed canary grass, prefers consistent moisture levels. It is tolerant of wet soils and can even thrive in shallow water, making it a suitable choice for areas near ponds or wetlands. However, it does not fare well in dry conditions and may require additional watering during prolonged dry spells. Ensuring the soil remains consistently moist is essential for optimal growth. When planting in more typical garden settings, regular watering to maintain soil moisture is beneficial. Avoid allowing the soil to dry out significantly between waterings to support healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phalaris arundinacea thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It requires ample sunlight for robust growth and vibrant foliage. Ideally, the plant should receive at least six hours of sunlight per day, although it can tolerate some shade. In regions with harsh, hot summers, providing some partial shade can help prevent the plant from experiencing stress due to excessive heat. When grown in shaded areas, the growth may become less vigorous and may affect the plant's ability to produce seeds. Therefore, ensuring adequate sunlight exposure will yield the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phalaris arundinacea involves trimming back dead or damaged foliage to encourage new growth and manage its spread, as it can be quite invasive. This can typically be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Cutting back the plant to the ground can help rejuvenate it and maintain its appearance. Additionally, removing any seed heads before they mature can help prevent unwanted spreading. Regular monitoring and pruning are advised to keep the plant contained, especially if it is planted in areas where its vigorous growth may interfere with other plants."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"reed canary grass","description":"Phalaris arundinacea, sometimes known as reed canary grass, is a tall, perennial bunchgrass that commonly forms extensive single-species stands along the margins of lakes and streams and in wet open areas, with a wide distribution in Europe, Asia, northern Africa and North America. Other common names for the plant include gardener's-garters in English, alpiste roseau in French, rohrglanzgras in German, kusa-yoshi in Japanese, caniço-malhado in Portuguese, and hierba cinta and pasto cinto in Spanish.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["reed canary grass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Phalaris arundinacea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11403,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Galanthus elwesii, commonly known as Elwes' snowdrop, prefers consistently moist soil, particularly during its growing season in late winter to early spring. It is important not to allow the soil to dry out completely, as this can hinder its growth. However, the soil should be well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to bulb rot. In summer, when the plant enters dormancy, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry more between waterings. In general, maintaining even moisture while avoiding extremes is key to healthy Galanthus elwesii growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Galanthus elwesii prefers to grow in partial to full shade, mimicking its natural habitat beneath trees or shrubs. Too much direct sunlight, especially in warmer climates, can cause the plant to dry out quickly or scorch the delicate leaves and flowers. A spot with dappled sunlight or afternoon shade is ideal. However, some morning sun can benefit the plant to encourage flowering. When planted in a garden setting, try to position them where they receive protection from extreme midday sun, ensuring a healthy growth cycle and vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Galanthus elwesii is minimal. It is primarily about tidying up rather than shaping the plant. Once the flowering period concludes, allow the foliage to die back naturally. This is important because the leaves continue to photosynthesize and store energy in the bulb for next year’s growth. Only remove dead or yellowing leaves when they pull away easily, which usually happens in late spring to early summer. Avoid cutting back the foliage too early, as this can affect the plant’s vigor and flowering potential in the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"greater snowdrop","description":"Galanthus elwesii (Elwes's snowdrop, greater snowdrop) is one of a number of species of the genus Galanthus, herbaceous, perennial, bulbous plants belonging to the family Amaryllidaceae. It is a native of the Caucasus.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Turkey","Ukraine","Greece"],"other_name":["greater snowdrop"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Galanthus elwesii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season, it's crucial to monitor the soil moisture and water accordingly. In areas with intense sunlight, some afternoon shade may help to protect the plant from heat stress. Ensure the plant receives consistent sunlight exposure to support healthy growth and fruiting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vaccinium myrtilloides should be done during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Pruning helps to maintain shape, remove any dead or diseased branches, and promote vigorous new growth. Focus on removing any crossing or congested branches to improve airflow within the bush. This will help prevent diseases and encourage better fruit production. Thin out older stems to rejuvenate the plant, ensuring you leave a good structure of younger, more productive branches. Annual maintenance pruning helps to keep the plant healthy and productive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"velvetleaf blueberry","description":"Vaccinium myrtilloides is a shrub with common names including common blueberry, velvetleaf huckleberry, velvetleaf blueberry, Canadian blueberry, and sourtop blueberry. It is also known to occur in Montana and Washington....","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["velvetleaf blueberry"],"pest_susceptibility":["Stem blight","Mummy berry","Anthracnose","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Vaccinium myrtilloides"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During dry periods, especially in the summer, the tree should be watered deeply once a week to maintain healthy growth, ensuring the water reaches the root zone. However, established trees are somewhat drought-tolerant and can survive on natural rainfall once they have developed a deep root system. It is advisable to monitor the soil moisture and adjust watering practices accordingly to prevent both overwatering and underwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ohio buckeye (Aesculus glabra) thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and development. In full sun conditions, the tree is likely to produce more flowers and seeds, while a partially shaded environment can be more beneficial if located in regions with very hot summers, as it can prevent leaf scorch and reduce water loss. However, the tree is adaptable and can tolerate a range of light conditions, although too much shade might result in reduced flowering and more sparse foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Aesculus glabra should be done to maintain the tree’s structure and remove any dead or diseased branches. This is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. It is recommended to remove any crossing or rubbing branches to promote a strong framework and good air circulation throughout the canopy. Be sure to make clean cuts at the branch collar to ensure proper healing. Pruning for size control is generally not necessary for Ohio buckeye, as it naturally has a well-defined shape, but occasional thinning may be required to encourage better air flow and light penetration."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Ohio buckeye","description":"The tree species Aesculus glabra is commonly known as Ohio buckeye, American buckeye, or  fetid buckeye. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12505,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lupinus arizonicus, commonly known as the Arizona lupine, prefers well-drained soil and requires consistent watering, especially during its growing season. However, it is drought-tolerant once established. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Aim to water in the early morning or late evening to reduce evaporation. In particularly dry climates or during hot spells, you may need to increase the frequency to keep the soil lightly moist but do not allow the plant to sit in standing water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lupinus arizonicus thrives in full sun conditions. It requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight every day to perform well, which aids in producing vibrant flowers and maintaining robust growth. If planted in partial shade, the plant may not bloom as profusely and could develop leggy or weak stems. Therefore, selecting a site with consistent sunlight exposure is crucial for optimal growth. In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from excessive heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lupinus arizonicus is not typically extensive. You should prune after the flowering season has ended to encourage new growth and manage its shape. Remove spent blooms (deadhead) to prevent the plant from using energy to produce seeds, which can also prolong its blooming period. Trim away any dead or yellowing foliage to maintain plant health and appearance. If the plant becomes leggy, a more substantial cut back can encourage a bushier form the following season. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arizona lupine","description":"Lupinus arizonicus (Arizona lupine) is a flowering plant in the family Fabaceae, native to the Mojave and Sonoran Deserts, where it can be found growing in open places and sandy washes below 1,100 metres (3,600 ft) elevation. It is common around Joshua Tree National Park and Death Valley National Park in California.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Arizona lupine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Lupinus arizonicus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly","Dry","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure the substrate or the growing medium remains damp but not waterlogged. It is critical to maintain the humidity levels around 85-90%. Misting the growing area periodically with water will help maintain moisture, but take care not to over-water, as this can lead to mold or other fungal issues. Using a hygrometer can aid in monitoring the moisture levels effectively. The goal is to mimic a natural forest floor environment, which is typically evenly moist but rarely saturated."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Agaricus bitorquis is typically cultivated indoors or in controlled environments where direct sunlight is not advisable. These mushrooms thrive in low-light conditions, mimicking their natural habitat under forest canopies. Indirect light is sufficient for their growth. Fluorescent lamps or LED grow lights are commonly used to provide the necessary lighting conditions without overheating or drying out the growing space. Consistent temperatures and low light contribute to a successful yield, making the management of artificial lighting pivotal for indoor cultivation efforts."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not a conventional practice with Agaricus bitorquis, as it is with traditional garden plants. However, it's necessary to manage harvested mushrooms regularly to encourage ongoing production. When removing the mushrooms, carefully twist and pull them out of the substrate or use a clean knife to cut at the base, avoiding damage to the growing mycelium. Ensure old, decaying mushrooms are promptly removed to prevent contamination and the spread of disease. Keeping the growing environment tidy and free from expired growth will help maintain a healthy cycle for the mushrooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pavement Mushroom","description":"Agaricus bitorquis is an edible white mushroom of the genus Agaricus, similar to the common button mushroom that is sold commercially. The name supersedes Agaricus rodmani. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11799,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ambrosia psilostachya, commonly known as western ragweed, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. It primarily thrives in arid and semi-arid regions, making it ideal for low-water gardening. During its initial growth phase, ensure the soil is consistently moist but not waterlogged. Once matured, it should only be watered sparingly, typically once every two weeks in dry, hot conditions or when the soil has completely dried out. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other fungal diseases, so it's essential to avoid excess moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This hardy plant thrives in full sunlight, requiring exposure to direct sunlight for at least six to eight hours a day for optimal growth. Ambrosia psilostachya can tolerate part shade, but will generally exhibit more vigorous growth and flowering when given full sun. If grown in shaded conditions, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers, impacting its overall aesthetic and health. Additionally, providing ample sunlight helps to reduce humidity around the plant, thus decreasing the likelihood of fungal issues, which it is prone to if grown in damp, shady conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ambrosia psilostachya is generally not necessary for the plant's health, but it can help manage its spread and ensure a tidier appearance in managed landscapes. If pruning is desired, it is best to cut back the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Removing the dead or damaged stems at this time can promote new, healthy growth. Throughout the growing season, occasional trimming of spent flowers and leggy or oversized growth can help control its robust nature. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease entry."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"western ragweed","description":"Ambrosia psilostachya is a species of ragweed known by the common names Cuman ragweed and perennial ragweed, and western ragweed.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["western ragweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Ambrosia psilostachya"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, it can tolerate partial shade, where it may receive less direct sunlight. When grown in shady areas, the plant may experience a reduction in flowering and a more elongated growth habit. Ensuring adequate sunlight is crucial for robust growth and helps maintain the plant's favorable conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sparganium eurycarpum is generally minimal, focusing on removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain healthy growth and appearance. Cutting back the old flowering stalks after they have finished blooming is advisable to prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively if spreading is not desired. Pruning can be done in late fall or early spring before new growth begins. Use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease. Regular maintenance can help control the plant's size and promote a tidier appearance in managed landscapes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"big bur-reed","description":"Sparganium eurycarpum is a species of bur-reed known by the common names broadfruit bur-reed and giant bur-reed. It is native to wetlands in Eurasia and North America. It is a clonal perennial, spreading by below-ground rhizomes. The common name, bur-reed, arises from the distinctive round clusters of fruits that take the form of a mace. It can be distinguished from all other species of bur-reed by the presence of two stigmas.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["big bur-reed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Sparganium eurycarpum"],"soil":["Wet","Marshy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the summer months, when the plant enters dormancy, reduce watering significantly. Allow the soil to dry slightly between watering during this period to prevent root rot. Ensure good drainage to avoid sitting water. Adjust frequency based on climate and soil conditions, as over-watering can lead to fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola pedunculata thrives in partial sunlight conditions, preferring some morning sun with afternoon shade. Adjust the positioning during different seasons to ensure adequate sun exposure while preventing overexposure to harsh sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Viola pedunculata involves trimming away any dead or damaged leaves and stems to encourage healthy growth and flowering. It is best to perform light pruning after the flowering season to remove spent flowers and prevent the plant from expending energy on seed production. This will also help maintain the plant’s compact shape. Should the plant become too leggy or overgrown, more extensive pruning can be carried out, but avoid heavy pruning during active growth periods. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent damage and disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"California Golden Violet","description":"Viola pedunculata, the California golden violet, Johnny jump up, or yellow pansy, is a perennial yellow wildflower of the coast and coastal ranges in California and northwestern Baja California. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12306,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Triticum aestivum, commonly known as common wheat, requires consistent watering, especially during its growth phases. It prefers well-draining soil to prevent waterlogging, which can damage the roots. The key is to maintain evenly moist soil without letting it become too dry or too saturated. In the initial growth stages, water more frequently, ensuring the soil remains moist but not soaked. As the plant matures, reduce the frequency but allow deeper soil penetration for each watering. Monitor rainfall if grown outdoors, as too much or too little water can affect growth and yield."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Triticum aestivum thrives in full sunlight, ideally receiving at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. This plant is best suited to areas with long, sunny periods, which is crucial for its growth and development phases. Insufficient sunlight can lead to stunted growth and lower grain yield. Ensure that the planting location is in an open field or garden that is not shaded by buildings or trees for optimal sunlight exposure. Consistently good sunlight will promote healthy photosynthesis, contributing to strong growth and abundant production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically a requirement for Triticum aestivum as it is with some other plants. However, ensuring that dead or diseased tillers are removed can help maintain a healthy growth environment. This can also prevent the spread of disease. Generally, maintaining a dense but healthy planting space will maximize yield, so focus on proper crop rotation and health rather than individual plant pruning. If you are growing it in a garden, simply remove any weeds or dried leaves to prevent competition for nutrients."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bread Wheat","description":"Common wheat (Triticum aestivum), also known as bread wheat, is a cultivated wheat species. About 95% of the wheat produced is common wheat, which is the most widely grown of all crops, and the cereal with the highest monetary yield.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Middle East","Southwest Asia"],"other_name":["Bread Wheat"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Stem rust","Aphids","Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Triticum aestivum"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, during periods of extreme drought, occasional watering may be beneficial to maintain its vigor. Be careful not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot or other fungal issues. Ensure the plant receives at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal health and resilience. If growing in partial shade, monitor for any signs of stunted growth or reduced flowering, which may indicate a need for increased sunlight exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cirsium arvense involves primarily controlling its growth since it is known to be an aggressive and invasive species. Regular mowing or cutting back the plant to ground level can help manage its spread by preventing it from flowering and setting seed. This should be done several times a year, typically from early spring to late summer. Cutting it back before it flowers will help reduce its ability to propagate. Always use clean tools to prevent the spread of any potential diseases and dispose of the cuttings to avoid them taking root elsewhere."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"creeping thistle","description":"Cirsium arvense is a perennial species of flowering plant in the family Asteraceae, native throughout Europe and northern Asia, and widely introduced elsewhere. In extremely hot, dry conditions, a deep watering once a month will help maintain its health and vigor."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Juniperus grandis thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of bright sunlight per day to maintain its dense foliage and healthy growth.
